subject: Remove multiple database scaffolding
messages:
[{'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-09-06 18:21:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-09-06 19:04:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This is mostly good but you appear to have changed the behavior of the fixture somewhat. In its original form DB_SCHEMA is global so that whatever it's value is can be reused with different uses of the fixture. You made it per fixture.

What is happening is that the fixture is running the migrations once to create a set of database tables in the right form, and then dump the SQL that represents the resulting schema of a database "now". If the fixture gets instantiated multiple times  in the same process it can avoid the migration step if DB_SCHEMA has value.

If I'm right about the above, the change you've made will slow the tests down, but probably not very much because there aren't many tables or migrations to deal with. But since we like them fast, we should, short term, put it back.

Assuming I'm right, of course, I may not be.

Then, longer term, we shouldn't do the migration in this fixture at all, we should use a create_all as shown in _create() in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/600161/1/placement/cmd/manage.py for the usual database using tests.

And have a separate "run me all the migrations" smoke test that only happens once in the functional tests instead of many times.'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-09-11 19:29:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@chris - ok, I'll move the db_schema to the module level, but it's gonna be lowercase, as it isn't constant."}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-09-11 19:45:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-09-11 20:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

thanks'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-09-13 21:41:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Remove multiple database scaffolding

Placement uses a single database, so the code required to support
multiple databases that came from Nova is not needed.

I also changed the global 'session_configured' to lowercase, as it is
not a constant. The 'setUp' method was moved above the 'cleanup' method
to respect the flow of time in the Universe.

Change-Id: If0eb17164c8c8bfdee68761aa15ad0eedbacb957

commit_message:
Validate member address for lb graph creation

We added the configuration option for reserved IP addresses that cannot
be used for load balancer member addresses, but the validation for lb
graph creation is missing.

This patch should also be backported to stable branches.

Change-Id: I5ba30d29e7a35b370f21d9f68ec43efed74dd363
Story: 2003413
Task: 24555
(cherry picked from commit 809915c4b17286209135a81d6c3c49f92d76a0e9)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-26 21:40:59.000000000', 'message': "object-replicator: separate workers for primary/handoffs

After a ring rebalance, it's a good idea to move (now-handoff)
partitions to their new homes as quickly as possible. Having one
replicator process responsible for both primary and handoff partitions
can slow that process down since partitions are processed in
order. The handoffs_first option helps, but a given replication pass
must still process all the primaries and all the handoffs before the
next pass can start.

This commit adds a new replicator_handoff_workers option to the object
replicator's configuration file.

If configured like so:

    replicator_workers = N
    replicator_handoff_workers = M

then there will be N worker processes handling only primary partitions
and M worker processes handling handoff partitions. This gives
operators a way to control the relative priorities.

If replicator_handoff_workers is not set, then there will be N
workers, each responsible for primary and handoff partitions, just as
before.

Change-Id: Iad468610b66b1bce82ab23f158a6f20e97025216
NOTE: this is still a work in progress; the sample configs and docs and stuff are not updated yet.
"}, {'created': '2018-06-26 22:19:33.000000000', 'message': "object-replicator: separate workers for primary/handoffs

After a ring rebalance, it's a good idea to move (now-handoff)
partitions to their new homes as quickly as possible. Having one
replicator process responsible for both primary and handoff partitions
can slow that process down since partitions are processed in
order. The handoffs_first option helps, but a given replication pass
must still process all the primaries and all the handoffs before the
next pass can start.

This commit adds a new replicator_handoff_workers option to the object
replicator's configuration file.

If configured like so:

    replicator_workers = N
    replicator_handoff_workers = M

then there will be N worker processes handling only primary partitions
and M worker processes handling handoff partitions. This gives
operators a way to control the relative priorities.

If replicator_handoff_workers is not set, then there will be N
workers, each responsible for primary and handoff partitions, just as
before.

Note that replicator_handoff_workers = 0 is invalid. That setting
would cause only primary partitions to be replicated, and that's not a
good idea for anyone.

Change-Id: Iad468610b66b1bce82ab23f158a6f20e97025216
NOTE: this is still a work in progress; the sample configs and docs and stuff are not updated yet.
"}, {'created': '2018-06-28 00:49:54.000000000', 'message': "object-replicator: separate workers for primary/handoffs

After a ring rebalance, it's a good idea to move (now-handoff)
partitions to their new homes as quickly as possible. Having one
replicator process responsible for both primary and handoff partitions
can slow that process down since partitions are processed in
order. The handoffs_first option helps, but a given replication pass
must still process all the primaries and all the handoffs before the
next pass can start.

This commit adds a new replicator_handoff_workers option to the object
replicator's configuration file.

If configured like so:

    replicator_primary_only_workers = N
    replicator_handoff_only_workers = M

then there will be N worker processes handling only primary partitions
and M worker processes handling handoff partitions. This gives
operators a way to control the relative priorities.

To use separate workers, the operator must set *both*
replicator_primary_only_workers and
replicator_handoff_only_workers. Setting just one is invalid, and the
replicator will refuse to start.

When both new config options are set, replicator_workers is
ignored. This way an operator cannot accidentally have primary-only,
handoff-only, and all-partitions workers at the same time.

Change-Id: Iad468610b66b1bce82ab23f158a6f20e97025216
"}, {'created': '2018-06-28 00:56:18.000000000', 'message': "object-replicator: separate workers for primary/handoffs

Change-Id: Iad468610b66b1bce82ab23f158a6f20e97025216
"}, {'created': '2018-06-28 17:35:01.000000000', 'message': "object-replicator: separate workers for primary/handoffs

commit_message:
object-replicator: separate workers for primary/handoffs

After a ring rebalance, it's a good idea to move (now-handoff)
partitions to their new homes as quickly as possible. Having one
replicator process responsible for both primary and handoff partitions
can slow that process down since partitions are processed in
order. The handoffs_first option helps, but a given replication pass
must still process all the primaries and all the handoffs before the
next pass can start.

This commit adds a new replicator_handoff_workers option to the object
replicator's configuration file.

If configured like so:

    replicator_primary_only_workers = N
    replicator_handoff_only_workers = M

then there will be N worker processes handling only primary partitions
and M worker processes handling handoff partitions. This gives
operators a way to control the relative priorities.

To use separate workers, the operator must set *both*
replicator_primary_only_workers and
replicator_handoff_only_workers. Setting just one is invalid, and the
replicator will refuse to start.

When both new config options are set, replicator_workers is
ignored. This way an operator cannot accidentally have primary-only,
handoff-only, and all-partitions workers at the same time.

Change-Id: Iad468610b66b1bce82ab23f158a6f20e97025216

commit_message:
Clean up role tests

Now that we're using the general templates, we can slim down
the role test definitions. We can also remove tests which are
not being watched, or which are fundamentally broken. With
this we can also remove unused scripts/plays.

We do the following:

1. We remove the 'upgrade' job, given that it's been broken
   all cycle due to the way the job executes and we need to
   regroup to figure out another way to do it.

Change-Id: I473b4162e141e05692e89f0420ea74c745dfc9e5

commit_message:
Include README in patrole_tempest_plugin/tests/api via symlink

This patch set adds a symlink from patrole_tempest_plugin/tests/api/
README.rst to the RBAC field guide under the docs/ folder. This is
the same thing Tempest does with its README file under its tempest/api
path: [0]

[0] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/tree/master/tempest/api

Change-Id: I0fb776b52828ceaa834885a8d097eb53efce0ba0

commit_message:
Make vlan_transparent in neutron.conf configurable from Undercloud

Allow plugins that support it to create VLAN transparent networks
The vlan_transparent determines if plugins that support it to
create VLAN transparent networks or not

Depends-On: I149237c12658201e44efdb1cd4851c7f154c6728
Change-Id: I2472fff376c172070d22d6dd90664145ab9d850e
Closes-Bug: 1786409

Make vlan_transparent in neutron.conf configurable

Allow plugins that support it to create VLAN transparent networks
The vlan_transparent determines if plugins that support it to
create VLAN transparent networks or not

commit_message:
Remove 35357 admin port

Use port 5000 as the keystone admin port since the 35357 endpoint
is being removed.

Change-Id: Iaa4698446c8a738ee18936e56661016ecccdebe0

commit_message:
Replace 35357 with 5000 for Keystone Admin Port

Based on the change in Keystone Install Guide [1]
and suggestion of Jean-Philippe Evrard in openstack-ansible-tests [2],
this patch replace port 35357 with 5000 for Keystone Admin Port.

For more details, please check similar changes which have been done
on other projects: Nova [3], Neutron [4], Cinder [5], Glance [6].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541857
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/569709
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/562812
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/566491
[5] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/565464
[6] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558932

Change-Id: Id66aba8e06fbd2a8699fcb7284a09af39a4a35ab

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-19 21:20:24.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/rocky

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: Ieae081420f376dc51f42ffc4a805f42aaa3f29a7
"}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/rocky

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: Ieae081420f376dc51f42ffc4a805f42aaa3f29a7

commit_message:

have been migrated to the git repositories owned by the tacker team.

See the python3-first goal document for details:

commit_message:
Add option to use /etc/nodepool files if subnodes is undefined

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/596887/ added a change
to use the ansible inventory variables.
These are not defined in the scenraio jobs. This review
adds the option to use the /etc/nodepool files
when subnodes is not defined.

Change-Id: If588067d45f7b7ed902a5c93b6fd75e3e9e552a6
Closes-Bug: #1792440

commit_message:
Rename files to remove 'placement'

When part of Nova, many files were named in such a way as to indicate
that they were separate from the nova files that did the same thing. Now
that that distinction is no longer needed, we can rename them to sound
more natural.

Additionally, references to these file names in other parts of the code
have been updated.

Change-Id: Id4439b4af827b64bbac213085ac74d1283c96db0

subject: Revert "Use dd conv=sparse when writing images to nodes"
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6133, 'name': 'yolanda.robla', 'email': 'yroblamo@redhat.com', 'username': 'yolanda.robla'}, {'_account_id': 10239, 'name': 'Dmitry Tantsur', 'email': 'dtantsur@protonmail.com', 'username': 'dtantsur'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 20414, 'name': 'Ian Pilcher', 'email': 'arequipeno@gmail.com', 'username': 'ipilcher'}, {'_account_id': 21909, 'name': 'Bob Fournier', 'email': 'bfournie@redhat.com', 'username': 'bfournie'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22600, 'name': 'Alexander Chuzhoy', 'email': 'sasha@redhat.com', 'username': 'achuzhoy'}, {'_account_id': 24245, 'name': 'Harald Jensås', 'email': 'hjensas@redhat.com', 'username': 'harald.jensas'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:51:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:52:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 22600, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:57:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Confirming that by removing 'conv=sparse', the issue with failed mounts gets resolved."}, {'account_id': 21909, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:59:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-09-13 16:00:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Should we make conv=sparse configurable (and off by default) maybe? The reason it was introduced is that using large whole-disk images was too hard?

This can be done in a follow-up if we want to backport it..'}, {'account_id': 21909, 'date': '2018-09-13 16:00:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This would need to be backported to Queens and Pike.'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-09-13 16:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I agree that we can do it in a followup. Are you talking of adding the logic for configuring that only on Ironic, or also adding some logic to enable that on installers (TripleO) ?'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-09-13 16:05:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Both? We still need to do something when whole disk images are large and consist mostly of zeroes.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2018-09-13 16:25:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20414, 'date': '2018-09-13 16:37:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Both? We still need to do something when whole disk images are
 > large and consist mostly of zeroes.

Indeed.  When using 100GB whole-disk images without conv=sparse, we end up sending ~90GB of zeroes over ther network to *every* overcloud node.  It makes whole-disk images basically unusable.

I can help wondering if there's another way to avoid the failure, maybe by zeroing the volume before writing out the image?  (I'm not familiar with security hardened volumes, so I'm assuming that some sort of checksum check is failing, because of garbage that doesn't get overwritten with conv=sparse.)"}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-09-13 17:28:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

So we can land this patch now. Then do a followup to enable config for sparse, and off by default. We can document it, and specify that if we enable sparse=true, we also need to enable disk cleanup in order to make it work.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-09-13 17:44:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I've asked Yolonda to update the commit message with the a story number for tracking, since this will need to be backported."}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-09-13 17:50:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-09-13 18:12:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-09-13 18:12:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-09-13 20:15:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/rocky as commit a61f7fcd3d018bdf4f09e7c02baa80c7f629de20'}]

commit_message:
Revert "Use dd conv=sparse when writing images to nodes"

When using volumes, and having empty ones, the volumes are failing to
mount when using conv=sparse with dd . This is causing security
hardened volumes :
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/tree/elements/overcloud-secure/block-device-default.yaml

To fail when mounted via iscsi

This reverts commit ab0492a364b8d5ed20948e4de67f03dacaa3c38d.

Story: #2003755
Task: #26441
Change-Id: I03f53a50ada9aabe9e3fbb71106d5190ae110e01

commit_message:
remove job settings for Quality Assurance repositories

This is a mechanically generated patch to remove the job settings that
have been migrated to the git repositories owned by the Quality Assurance team.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

This updates legacy-periodic-tempest-dsvm-oslo-latest-full-master as
well to mark it running on master and removes unused irrelevant-files
for a periodic job.

Change-Id: I6c63fef537800165cb44c1a644f90b565edf9115
Story: #2002586
Task: #24327

health LGTM 
per Carlos housekeeper should be fine because it rechecks

We should add logic to the worker to be resilient to db outages as well, e.g. if the DB goes away after we marked an LB PENDING_ in the api and it got picked up by the worker we will never reach ERROR or ACTIVE. So worker needs to wait, too, instead of initiate a rollback

API threads are also governed by the uwsgi request timeout, e.g. after a certain time uwsgi will kill the threat thus losing the request. On the API side we should return 503 and have the client retry.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-09-13 16:52:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

The controller worker already supports this with the DB timeouts in the config file.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-09-13 17:05:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-09-13 17:46:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-07 22:27:06.000000000', 'message': 'Make health checks resilient to DB outages

Octavia is struggling with proper handling of DB connectivity issues
bringing down all running loadbalancers. Octavia tries to failover
amphorae and can fail in one of the following stages:

1. Octavia can't create new amphora because Nova isn't ready yet after
   DB outage. Nova-API throws 500, Octavia nukes amphora instance and
   won't try to recreate it again.
2. Octavia tries to recreate amphora instance but it get stuck in
   PENDING_CREATE forever
3. Octavia fails completely reporting DB connection issues, leaving some
   amphoras in error, some in pending_delete as bellow: It affects also
   HA deployments.

This patch fixes that by wrapping the DB check for health, waiting for
the connection to be re-established and sleeping off the full
"heartbeat_timeout" interval.

Story: 2003575
Task: 24871

Change-Id: I7b30cd31e1ce0cf9dab61484f4404f1c6ccddd5e

commit_message:
Make health checks resilient to DB outages

Octavia is struggling with proper handling of DB connectivity issues
bringing down all running loadbalancers. Octavia tries to failover
amphorae and can fail in one of the following stages:

1. Octavia can't create new amphora because Nova isn't ready yet after
   DB outage. Nova-API throws 500, Octavia nukes amphora instance and
   won't try to recreate it again.
2. Octavia tries to recreate amphora instance but it gets stuck in
   PENDING_CREATE forever.
3. Octavia fails completely reporting DB connection issues, leaving some
   amphoras in error, some in pending_delete as bellow: It affects also
   HA deployments.

This patch fixes that by wrapping the DB check for health, waiting for
the connection to be re-established and sleeping off the full
"heartbeat_timeout" interval.

Story: 2003575
Task: 24871

Change-Id: I7b30cd31e1ce0cf9dab61484f4404f1c6ccddd5e

commit_message:
Set CONF.image_feature_enabled.api_v1 default to False

Glance v1 APIs are deprecated and v2 APIs are current one,
but CONF.image_feature_enabled.api_v1 now defaults to True,
so CONF.image_feature_enabled.api_v1 must be explicitly set
to False in tempest.conf to avoid using api_v1, which is
annoying. So this is to set CONF.image_feature_enabled.api_v1
default to False.

Change-Id: Iab3a209c744375bf2618afc00a3f7731b62f557e

commit_message:
Follow devstack-plugin-ceph job rename

The devstack-plugin-ceph jobs have moved in-repo and renamed, follow
rename.

Remove post job  publish-openstack-python-branch-tarball,
it's part of python-jobs template.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/543048
Change-Id: I4bcd77d4b1d09d026ac3459312e8454878201658

Address issues with flask conversion of os-federation

This change addresses the following issues with the flask conversion:

* Filter attributes on get_idp (added to wrap_member)

commit_message:
Introduce container_cli parameter for undercloud.conf

This parameter, default to 'docker' for now, can be changed to 'podman'
if we want to deploy an Undercloud with Podman instead of Docker.

blueprint podman-support

Change-Id: I8e83a3903f6c67087d4e18734a61661dbd597185

[{'created': '2018-09-13 17:17:52.000000000', 'message': 'Gate install of tmpfiles configuration

The vhost-user tmpfiles configuration is only applicable in deployments
using libvirt/kvm with nova-compute.

Ensure appropriate user and group exists before installing tmpfiles.d
configuration.

Change-Id: I471ff459e5f979cb6781193fb074f6f5f7ee967f
Closes-Bug: 1792414
'}]
commit_message:
Gate install of tmpfiles configuration

The vhost-user tmpfiles configuration is only applicable in deployments
using libvirt/kvm with nova-compute.

Ensure appropriate user and group exists before installing tmpfiles.d
configuration.

Change-Id: I471ff459e5f979cb6781193fb074f6f5f7ee967f
Closes-Bug: 1792414

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-12 03:16:46.000000000', 'message': 'Fix deprecated_name in the help message in config.py

1. vnc.vnc_enabled in nova.conf is deprecated, and vnc.enabled
   is used instead, so help message of vnc_console should be fixed
   accordingly.
2. The format "nova.conf: DEFAULT.enable_instance_password" is the
   clearest one to mention the config item in nova.conf, so change
   all the occurrences to this format.

Change-Id: Iec8c6aeafd04d6449f7c5250e9953e80eb8a9151
'}]
commit_message:
Fix deprecated_name in the help message in config.py

1. vnc.vnc_enabled in nova.conf is deprecated, and vnc.enabled
   is used instead, so help message of vnc_console should be fixed
   accordingly.
2. The format "nova.conf: DEFAULT.enable_instance_password" is the
   clearest one to mention the config item in nova.conf, so change
   all the occurrences to this format.

Change-Id: Iec8c6aeafd04d6449f7c5250e9953e80eb8a9151

messages:
[{'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-09-10 17:17:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20722, 'date': '2018-09-11 07:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-09-11 22:10:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Will the link will be valid once there is a release containing placement, no?'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-09-12 23:00:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Why is this patch underneath https://review.openstack.org/#/c/602187/ ?'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-09-12 23:12:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Why is this patch underneath https://review.openstack.org/#/c/602187/
 > ?

Because the name change was for the sake of releasing to pypi [1] and on pypi the readme is exposed as the explanation of the project, so it was useful to bring the two together to make [1] happen as part of the requirements to make infra happen.


[1] https://pypi.org/project/openstack-placement/'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-13 17:18:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

LGTM'}]

Also, warn readers who are reading on GitHub[1] that they

commit_message:
Update README to warn of status

Update README.rst to change from nova to placement and to
indicate to the reader that the repository is in flux and
not currently a finished thing.

Also, warn readers who are reading on GitHub[1] that they
may not be in the right place.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/placement

Change-Id: I32cb7ff0f1a578e40f259f7e28ca9af7cef85549

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-03 23:14:22.000000000', 'message': "Update RequestSpec.flavor on resize_revert

Since I8abdf58a6537dd5e15a012ea37a7b48abd726579 in Newton
we update the RequestSpec.flavor to the new flavor during
a resize. However, if the resize is reverted, we didn't
revert the RequestSpec.flavor to the previous flavor
on the instance, which could cause issues later when
moving the instance since the scheduler will get a
RequestSpec with a flavor that doesn't match the actual
flavor on the instance.

This fixes the bug by updating the RequestSpec.flavor
with instance.old_flavor on resize_revert in the API.
Functional test wrinkles are added.

This fix was ported from the starlingx-staging/stx-nova
repo commit 71acfeae0.

Change-Id: Ic6e74702f2a5b57b437f4ffdfbc86c1e34cdac7d
Closes-Bug: #1785339
"}]
commit_message:
Update RequestSpec.flavor on resize_revert

Since I8abdf58a6537dd5e15a012ea37a7b48abd726579 in Newton
we update the RequestSpec.flavor to the new flavor during
a resize. However, if the resize is reverted, we didn't
revert the RequestSpec.flavor to the previous flavor
on the instance, which could cause issues later when
moving the instance since the scheduler will get a
RequestSpec with a flavor that doesn't match the actual
flavor on the instance.

This fixes the bug by updating the RequestSpec.flavor
with instance.old_flavor on resize_revert in the API.
Functional test wrinkles are added.

This fix was ported from the starlingx-staging/stx-nova
repo commit 71acfeae0.

Change-Id: Ic6e74702f2a5b57b437f4ffdfbc86c1e34cdac7d
Closes-Bug: #1785339

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-20 23:03:14.000000000', 'message': "DVR: Fix allowed_address_pair IP, ARP table update by neutron agent

Allowed_address_pair IP when associated with a network port will
inherit the services MAC.
Right now the ARP entry is updated with the last MAC that it is
associated with. But when allowed_address_pair IPs are used in
the context of VRRP the MAC keeps switching between the MASTER
and SLAVE. VRRP instance sends out GARP, but the ARP entry in the
router namespace is not getting updated based on the GARP.

This might cause the VRRP IP and the service using the IP to fail.

Since we having been adding the ARP entry with NUD state as
PERMANENT, the ARP entries are set for ever and does not adopt the
GARP sent out by the VRRP instance.

This will cause instances associated with DVR routers to have a
service interruption.

So the proposed patch will add the ARP entry for the Allowed address
pair with NUD for 'REACHABLE'.
This allows the Allowed_address_pair IP MAC to be updated on the
fly.

Change-Id: I43c3471f5d259e8c2ee1685398a06a4680c0bfcd
Closes-Bug: #1608400
"}, {'created': '2018-03-21 21:44:04.000000000', 'message': "DVR: Fix allowed_address_pair IP, ARP table update by neutron agent

commit_message:
DVR: Fix allowed_address_pair IP, ARP table update by neutron agent

Allowed_address_pair IP when associated with a network port will
inherit the services MAC.
Right now the ARP entry is updated with the last MAC that it is
associated with. But when allowed_address_pair IPs are used in
the context of VRRP the MAC keeps switching between the MASTER
and SLAVE. VRRP instance sends out GARP, but the ARP entry in the
router namespace is not getting updated based on the GARP.

This might cause the VRRP IP and the service using the IP to fail.

Since we having been adding the ARP entry with NUD state as
PERMANENT, the ARP entries are set for ever and does not adopt the
GARP sent out by the VRRP instance.

This will cause instances associated with DVR routers to have a
service interruption.

So the proposed patch will add the ARP entry for the Allowed address
pair with NUD for 'REACHABLE'.
This allows the Allowed_address_pair IP MAC to be updated on the
fly.

Change-Id: I43c3471f5d259e8c2ee1685398a06a4680c0bfcd
Closes-Bug: #1608400
(cherry-picked from commit fbe308bdc12191c187343b5ef103dea9af738380)

[{'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-02-13 13:48:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-02-13 16:34:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

I'm not exactly convinced we need need this and have mechanism concerns.  I'm also concerned because instead of DHCP, in this case we would have to become the address manager, or be told or able to find out what the address management is, which increases the complexity to the point that it may only be viable for use with full integrated stacks. That being said, we already provide configuration information over virtual floppy drives in one or two places, so it could be a viable path to support more complex use cases, however at the same time we would likely also just need to detail it as "how to perform L3 route delineated deployments with ironic" and then offer vendor specific mechanisms like what is proposed in this case.

Another thing that I just realized, this will require a new network interface that can be paired with the new boot interface, and potentially class changes to existing interface drivers because it assumes static L3 network where ironic has all of the required configuration. In this case, we likely don't have the ability to actually have cleaning/provisioning networks, but we could also use the network interface to return addressing so we have a means of use that is neutron integrated, and not neutron integrated.'}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-02-15 14:28:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for your valuable inputs.
I made this proposal based on a PoC with Ironic configured in Standalone mode. IP network configurations for target nodes were allotted by a Local Configuration Management server.
I will make further study on how to use Neutron networks in this context and get back.'}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-02-28 14:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-02-28 14:38:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I wonder if we could do this different and benefit other usecases? (e.g edge compute nodes where no neutron dhcp-agent is deployed on the edge.)'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2018-05-18 07:36:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

Looking over this another time. I realize my previous comments are a bit off. I read this as a way to provide the network configuration for the actual instance. Re-reading I understand, this is focused at configuring IPA so that it can deploy the image to the disk? Not configuring the instance? (Curious, how will the instance networking be configured?)

Having some background from TheForman the whole idea of building both an iso and a floppy image and mount two virtual media devices seem backwards to me. Why not just put it all in the cdrom iso image ... (TheForman uses https://github.com/theforeman/foreman_bootdisk - which can create a tiny cdrom iso with iPXE + iPXE config file with static network configuration and the url to fetch kernel+ramdisk.)

The iso + floppy virtual media seems to be the way it's done in ilo and irmc drivers, so I guess this is fine."}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-05-22 06:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-05-22 06:59:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

(3 comments)

Fixed typo!


>>Harald Jensås:
>>Looking over this another time. I realize my previous comments are a bit off. I read this as a way to provide the network configuration for the actual instance. Re-reading I understand, this is focused at configuring IPA so that it can deploy the image to the disk? Not configuring the instance? 

Yes! that's the idea.

>>(Curious, how will the instance networking be configured?)
Instance configuration would be done by configdrive written to the target disk by IPA during provisioning. Ref: https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configdrive.html#when-used-with-compute-service and https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configdrive.html#when-used-standalone


>> Having some background from TheForman the whole idea of building both an iso and a floppy image and mount two virtual media devices seem backwards to me. Why not just put it all in the cdrom iso image ... (TheForman uses https://github.com/theforeman/foreman_bootdisk - which can create a tiny cdrom iso with iPXE + iPXE config file with static network configuration and the url to fetch kernel+ramdisk.)
>> The iso + floppy virtual media seems to be the way it's done in ilo and irmc drivers, so I guess this is fine.

This is a good Idea. At Nokia we already use this method of deployment (with Nokia Ironic drivers, which uses this blueprint already :)). The compelling reason for this is, Nokia hardware doesn't support attaching 2 virtual devices. 
But the down side for this is you need to create one ISO images for every target node. If the ironic-deploy-iso is arround 200MB, config floppy is about 1MB. This puts a big disk requirement.

Do you still suggest to add this method in the Spec, I can add it?"}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2018-05-23 18:16:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

> (3 comments)
 > 
 > Fixed typo!
 > 
 > 
 > >>Harald Jensås:
 > >>Looking over this another time. I realize my previous comments
 > are a bit off. I read this as a way to provide the network
 > configuration for the actual instance. Re-reading I understand,
 > this is focused at configuring IPA so that it can deploy the image
 > to the disk? Not configuring the instance?
 > 
 > Yes! that's the idea.
 > 
 > >>(Curious, how will the instance networking be configured?)
 > Instance configuration would be done by configdrive written to the
 > target disk by IPA during provisioning. Ref: https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configdrive.html#when-used-with-compute-service
 > and https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configdrive.html#when-used-standalone
 > 
 > 
 > >> Having some background from TheForman the whole idea of building
 > both an iso and a floppy image and mount two virtual media devices
 > seem backwards to me. Why not just put it all in the cdrom iso
 > image ... (TheForman uses https://github.com/theforeman/foreman_bootdisk
 > - which can create a tiny cdrom iso with iPXE + iPXE config file
 > with static network configuration and the url to fetch
 > kernel+ramdisk.)
 > >> The iso + floppy virtual media seems to be the way it's done in
 > ilo and irmc drivers, so I guess this is fine.
 > 
 > This is a good Idea. At Nokia we already use this method of
 > deployment (with Nokia Ironic drivers, which uses this blueprint
 > already :)). The compelling reason for this is, Nokia hardware
 > doesn't support attaching 2 virtual devices.

So they do exist, hardware that only support 1 virtual device. :) (I was thinking to mention that this approach would be an issue in that case.)

 > But the down side for this is you need to create one ISO images for
 > every target node. If the ironic-deploy-iso is arround 200MB,
 > config floppy is about 1MB. This puts a big disk requirement.
 > 
Indeed, the size becomes an issue when the deploy iso is a full OS like the ironic-deploy-iso.
What the Foreman does with iPXE on the iso is that it creates a iso image smaller than 1MB in size. They generate it and for each deploy, so it is ephemeral and deleted afterwards. Even with 1000 servers simultaneously the disk requirements would not be very large. If an iPXE iso boots from virtual media and then the the 200MB ironic-deploy image is loaded via tftp/http by iPXE, it would be close to the same network traffic compared to attaching the 200MB ironic-deploy-iso to virtual-media. However virtual media is over the remote management card, 100Mbit interfaces still common? an iPXE iso would load the image over the server nic' where 10Gbit is more common. 

 > Do you still suggest to add this method in the Spec, I can add it?
If you already have drivers that use just one virtual media. You write the network config into ironic-deploy-iso? And there is hardware that does not support multiple virtual devices. Then I think it would be good to cover this.



I wonder if for the iPXE on a iso image, ref the Forman per-Host image[1], would make sense as a separate spec? This would be kind of a hybrid PXE/Virtual Media deployment. Ironic would have to do all the steps to set things up for PXE deploy + the steps to create the tiny iPXE cdrom iso.


[1] https://github.com/theforeman/foreman_bootdisk#per-host-images"}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-05-23 19:49:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Harald Jensås:

>> You write the network config into ironic-deploy-iso? 
Yes. We are making a 64K block floppy zipped image with networking data and appending it to the end of the ironic-deploy-iso. We read it and configure network in a systemd service, when the target boots with ironic-deploy-iso image, before IPA service starts.

The approach you mentioned is very interesting and it can address:
1. Duplicating ironic-deploy images.
2. Fetching 200MB+ image on low speed management card (100Mbit).

But this needs more study, and as you mentioned we can take it up as a different Spec, than mixing everything into single one.

For now I will add this approach of appending 64K block to the end of ironic-deploy-iso. 

Should we still keep separate virtual floppy option in this Spec (or) Just go with this virtual CD + 64K block method?'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2018-05-23 23:56:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> Harald Jensås:
 > 
 > >> You write the network config into ironic-deploy-iso?
 > Yes. We are making a 64K block floppy zipped image with networking
 > data and appending it to the end of the ironic-deploy-iso. We read
 > it and configure network in a systemd service, when the target
 > boots with ironic-deploy-iso image, before IPA service starts.
 > 
 > The approach you mentioned is very interesting and it can address:
 > 1. Duplicating ironic-deploy images.
 > 2. Fetching 200MB+ image on low speed management card (100Mbit).
 > 
 > But this needs more study, and as you mentioned we can take it up
 > as a different Spec, than mixing everything into single one.
 >

Agreed.

 > For now I will add this approach of appending 64K block to the end
 > of ironic-deploy-iso.
 > 
 > Should we still keep separate virtual floppy option in this Spec
 > (or) Just go with this virtual CD + 64K block method?

Keep the separate virtual floppy option, it fits with the existing drivers already using a virtual floppy.


+1 to add the approach you use by appending the zipped floppy image to the end of the iso as well.'}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-05-24 16:10:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-05-24 16:11:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Added option for appending vfat image to the boot iso as discussed with Harald Jensås.'}, {'account_id': 12356, 'date': '2018-05-24 16:17:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(7 comments)

some more comments to clarify things'}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-05-25 11:13:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-05-25 11:15:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

The only concern I have here is adding a general purpose "properties" field to ports. I think we already have bad experience with such things. If the new field is for network configuration, let's call it explicitly: l3_network_configuration or something. This will prevent people from trying to put random stuff there. Let's also work with os-net-config folks to provide a schema somewhere (there was a patch, I can try finding it), so that we can validate it.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-06-25 15:25:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(2 comments)

On a careful read, another thing caught my attention. Please clarify.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-06-26 01:33:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: -Code-Review

Removing +2 based on discussion during today's IRC meeting."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-06-26 09:36:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

(6 comments)

Thanks - interesting spec.

As config-drive is the OpenStack solution for passing network data to instances without requiring network connectivity, I'm just wondering if we should at least consider reusing that tool here. It seems to solve some problems outlined in this spec. OTOH, it would likely be a more heavyweight solution - it might may or may not add some bloat to the ramdisk."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-06-26 09:48:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

> (6 comments)
 > 
 > Thanks - interesting spec.
 > 
 > As config-drive is the OpenStack solution for passing network data
 > to instances without requiring network connectivity, I'm just
 > wondering if we should at least consider reusing that tool here. It
 > seems to solve some problems outlined in this spec. OTOH, it would
 > likely be a more heavyweight solution - it might may or may not add
 > some bloat to the ramdisk.

Just read through the previous comments on this and saw reference to glean, and remembered that it supports config-drives. I guess it would be a better alternative to cloud-init.

Moving to -1 as I'd like to see an answer on the question about interface names (L73). I can see how this might work in a standalone setup with a hand-crafted os-net-config blob, but not when used with neutron."}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2018-06-26 12:10:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 22194, 'date': '2018-08-31 11:00:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 28950, 'date': '2018-08-31 11:01:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-09-03 14:59:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-09-06 10:25:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2018-09-13 17:01:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I kind of think we should consider using the same schema that `network-data.json` in configdrive uses - this would give us a full-featured schema, and would allow people to use alternate tooling (cloud-init, ignition, etc) to configure the network.

But the downside is that this format isn't documented anywhere except an old spec: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/liberty/implemented/metadata-service-network-info.html

So, I'm fine with this spec as-is, but would like people to consider doing the configdrive format. I'll be okay with either option. But I'm going to be very sad when people want to add to this schema for bonding information and things like that."}]

commit_message:
Add new testing for cleanup with ansible interface

When using cleanup steps for ansible, we need to pass an
additional tags argument. Adding a new test to ensure that
the cleanup works correctly for ansible as well.

Change-Id: I40f4088287ef345708e3337d6cf31a95df9e0a23

Change-Id: I20d5c6e26b3258ecd9e20d69ff91a2ce0865c067
'}, {'created': '2018-06-29 10:55:09.000000000', 'message': 'Increase timeouts for standalone tests

The standalone tests are currently failing because they are
exhausting the 600 timeout, so increase it. Also increase
active/boot/associate/terminate timeouts, to give more time
to complete.

commit_message:
Increase timeouts for standalone tests

The standalone tests are currently failing because they are
exhausting the 600 timeout, so increase it. Also increase
active/boot/associate/terminate timeouts, to give more time
to complete.

Change-Id: I20d5c6e26b3258ecd9e20d69ff91a2ce0865c067

[{'created': '2018-09-12 23:03:26.000000000', 'message': 'Fix mock.patch usage in unit tests

There are various places where a patcher was started but never stopped
or the test stopped the wrong thing. This causes that the mocking is not
removed at the end of the test case leads to interfering tests.

Change-Id: I8e66154c19c125f3093c8a1990b0c79332996560
'}, {'created': '2018-09-13 02:54:13.000000000', 'message': 'Fix mock.patch usage in unit tests

There are various places where a patcher was started but never stopped
or the test stopped the wrong thing. This causes that the mocking is not
removed at the end of the test case execution. So the subsequnet test
cases executed by the same executor will see the same mocked function.
Depending on the test case exection order it can lead to intermittent
test failures.

Change-Id: I8e66154c19c125f3093c8a1990b0c79332996560
'}]
commit_message:
Fix mock.patch usage in unit tests

There are various places where a patcher was started but never stopped
or the test stopped the wrong thing. This causes that the mocking is not
removed at the end of the test case execution. So the subsequnet test
cases executed by the same executor will see the same mocked function.
Depending on the test case exection order it can lead to intermittent
test failures.

Change-Id: I8e66154c19c125f3093c8a1990b0c79332996560

commit_message:
Clean up bare raised pylint warning

Clean up bare raises warning by linter, pylint
complains about raising an exception specified
and not in the context of an exception handler.
Added an exception.

Change-Id: I1d77c6ab9849510c45fdd99dd57b71bde9a57da6
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chucks@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Install ceilometer dependency for ODL

Let os_neutron to install ceilometer as it's needed by
latest changes [1] in ODL mechanism driver.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/networking-odl/blob/master/requirements.txt#L21

Change-Id: Ice120b582cd2ddcff6340088554537bf013e306e
Signed-off-by: Periyasamy Palanisamy <periyasamy.palanisamy@ericsson.com>

Swift func tests are failing with this, so it doesn't seem to do the right thing.

http://logs.openstack.org/38/548938/2/check/legacy-swift-dsvm-functional/ddd8d49/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-03-01_16_18_30_591217"}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-03-28 02:52:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Good call. Looking at the logs, this patch raises another issue we should run the functional tests via Keystone authentication.

This patch removes tempauth as correct as I expected but it seems like the test runner is using tempauth authentication even the devstack gate attempts to setup the keystone for testing.

Let me try to add more fixes to resolve the testing issue.'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-09-13 16:28:05.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

We're moving. We don't need swift3 anymore, instead, I pushed another approach to make devstack work with the newest swift master. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/602126/"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-01 13:01:40.000000000', 'message': "Change devstack-swift to use keystone auth sample

When keystone auth is enabled.

With the complexity of setting difference using among swift3 and
authentications (tempauth, keystoneauth), current charactor
replacement would not work much as expected. And also Swift upstream
is now moving to welcome swift3 back into the repo again as s3api that
could be conflicted with current devstack setup.

To be simple the setup, let's use proxy-server.conf default pipeline
configuration for each authentication as possible because swift
proxy-server.conf-sample obviously have both tempauth and keystoneauth
examples.[1]

Once s3api get merged into swift msater, I'll rework around devstack
configuration to be match the namespace.

commit_message:
Change devstack-swift to use keystone auth sample

When keystone auth is enabled.

With the complexity of setting difference using among swift3 and
authentications (tempauth, keystoneauth), current charactor
replacement would not work much as expected. And also Swift upstream
is now moving to welcome swift3 back into the repo again as s3api that
could be conflicted with current devstack setup.

To be simple the setup, let's use proxy-server.conf default pipeline
configuration for each authentication as possible because swift
proxy-server.conf-sample obviously have both tempauth and keystoneauth
examples.[1]

Once s3api get merged into swift msater, I'll rework around devstack
configuration to be match the namespace.

Related-Change: I21e38884a2aefbb94b76c76deccd815f01db7362
Needed-by: Id5ac9840c6d8fef9d8bb62137dc5df061b27b45f

Change-Id: Iee5b63fb1094a7e1dcfef5e8c2a22b7b5f1c903d
1: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/etc/proxy-server.conf-sample#L95-L102

commit_message:
Fix the incorrect storyboard url

Using "repository_name" instead of "bug_project" to combine with the
"urlBase" string, if set use_storyboard to "True". storyboard URLs are
in this format:
"https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/project/"+"openstack/whereto"
not:
"https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/project/"+"whereto"

Change-Id: Ib553d95f22c7848a5bd537b8929a2d6e6625451b

commit_message:
make the project list template sharable

Move the main part of the project list template into a base template
and use it for the most recent few series. Leave the older series
alone because they vary a bit from the newer ones.

Change-Id: I6f9d443533bda87b1dffe90a4833449a89d307aa
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

Not all projects have project guides, so only link to the ones that do
have the guides.

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

[{'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-08-30 11:40:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-08-30 11:41:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hopefully this is correct.  I'm not entirely sure how the manuals "work" for releases; I'm guessing that a stable/queens and stable/rocky branches are required in each project?'}, {'account_id': 17765, 'date': '2018-08-30 12:17:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Hopefully this is correct.  I'm not entirely sure how the manuals
 > "work" for releases; I'm guessing that a stable/queens and
 > stable/rocky branches are required in each project?

yes, at least you need a stable branch and a publish-openstack-sphinx-docs job for each branch to build and publish the required docs first before you set links here. I couldn't found any branches in charm-guide, so I think you have only master branch and wants only change latest.yaml. So let the other files untouched :)'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-09-05 14:52:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-09-05 14:53:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've added branches to the relevant projects now; and asked for a recheck  -- We do really want queens and rocky releases of both those guides.  I'll keep checking back for other errors."}, {'account_id': 17765, 'date': '2018-09-06 12:21:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 17765, 'date': '2018-09-06 16:25:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The charm-guide is fine now for Rocky.
Now we need charm-deployment-guide in Queens. There is only a master version published.'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-09-07 08:26:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Frank; yes, I'm looking into why that is.  charm-deployment-guide project is a little strange in comparison with the other projects as it's ONLY a guide; I'm trying to see the differences from the other projects to see why it might not be building queens and rocky branches.  Thanks for keeping an eye on this one."}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2018-09-10 15:17:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for looking into this.  At the time of the OpenStack Rocky release there was indeed a `stable/rocky` branch cut for the `charm-deployment-guide` repository.

At present there are `stable/queens` and `stable/rocky` branches for both `charm-deployment-guide` and `charm-guide` repositories.

Anything else we need in place for restoring our presence in the Deployment guide index?'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2018-09-10 15:17:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 17765, 'date': '2018-09-11 17:15:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

there was a publishing job for charm-deployment-guide for stable/queens, but AFS data copy was skipped for unknown reasons: http://logs.openstack.org/df/dfe4f7c37e30aa5e2195915ac38db7aa4d8844fc/post/publish-deploy-guide/2d074c5/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-09-06_02_29_26_134673'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-09-12 06:31:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Problem is here http://logs.openstack.org/df/dfe4f7c37e30aa5e2195915ac38db7aa4d8844fc/post/publish-deploy-guide/2d074c5/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-09-06_02_29_26_134673

The root-marker file is at wrong path.

I'll look into it..."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-09-12 08:18:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/charm-deployment-guide/queens/ exists...'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-09-12 08:21:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

error is probably in our tooling, it reports at:

http://logs.openstack.org/38/598138/1/check/build-tox-manuals-checkbuild/90474c2/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-09-10_15_26_13_973747

 None set for charm-deployment-guide but https://docs.openstack.org/charm-deployment-guide/queens/index.html does not exist (404)

And that is the wrong URL, it should check instead https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/charm-deployment-guide/queens/'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-09-12 10:45:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

this fails since the tool expects that the base link works and deploy-guide is in addition.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-09-12 10:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So, needs an update to tools/www-generator.py - changes welcome...

I won't have time to dig further into this for now."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-09-12 12:20:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> error is probably in our tooling, it reports at:
 > 
 > http://logs.openstack.org/38/598138/1/check/build-tox-manuals-checkbuild/90474c2/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-09-10_15_26_13_973747
 > 
 > None set for charm-deployment-guide but https://docs.openstack.org/charm-deployment-guide/queens/index.html
 > does not exist (404)
 > 
 > And that is the wrong URL, it should check instead
 > https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/charm-deployment-guide/queens/

We have it check index.html on purpose because we want the directory to have an index.html so we can link directly to it, instead of having a bunch of other HTML files that are listed in the toctree in the parent directory. We had that in at least one project, and changed the validation to be more specific to deal with it.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-09-12 12:23:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > error is probably in our tooling, it reports at:

 > instead of having a bunch of other HTML files that are listed in
 > the toctree in the parent directory. We had that in at least one
 > project, and changed the validation to be more specific to deal
 > with it.

Oh, I didn't notice that the rest of the URL was actually different, too. So https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/charm-deployment-guide/queens/index.html exists. I'm not sure why the tool is not adding the "project-deploy-guide" prefix to the path in this case.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-09-12 12:54:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Doug, it checks
https://docs.openstack.org/charm-deployment-guide/queens/ instead of:

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/charm-deployment-
guide/queens/

The first URL is the problem'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-09-12 17:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2018-09-12 20:59:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
add a flag to indicate which projects have guides

Some of the projects publish documentation but not using the project
guide structure. Instead of requiring all projects listed to have a
default guide, add a flag that defaults to True and that can be
changed in the project data file(s).

Also add a default field to the URLSettings structure.

Change-Id: Ie2b6abafde5d4be85941fd977762bcbdf891d440
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

add a flag to only test urls for some projects

When running the template generator in test mode it is useful to be
able to only test one deliverable or project. Add a flag to do that.

Correct the wrong link URL

Contributor Guide to distinguish this document from the new
document aimed at all new OpenStack contributors. So this
patch correct the link. Refer to
https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/openstack-manuals/queens

commit_message:
Amends user/group ownership and adds find / stat

The security guide currently states that files be owned by `root
\ service` whereas complete ownership by either <service> or
`root` and variations of those two are acceptable.

This also changes the stat file cmd for exec under find to help
provide a check which contains the latest files in any given release
thereby not resulting in depreciated files still being listed.

Change-Id: I479b527e11a7a16eb20e62de446f5c4220196945

NetApp ONTAP driver currently have some issues with IPv6:
 - The URL is not properly formatted when using in management path
 - NFS driver breaks when handling IPv6 addresses
 - iSCSI driver creates a URL that is not properly formatted when
 using IPv6 addresses

This patch fixes all issues related to IPv6 on NetApp ONTAP drivers.

Closes-bug: 1788460
Change-Id: I6eeca47997c7134d6604874bea48eab7cab6c1a2
(cherry picked from commit 925376527e356ed14320716d0f72b48b13b8aecb)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix IPv6 for Cinder NetApp ONTAP drivers

NetApp ONTAP driver currently have some issues with IPv6:
 - The URL is not properly formatted when using in management path
 - NFS driver breaks when handling IPv6 addresses
 - iSCSI driver creates a URL that is not properly formatted when
 using IPv6 addresses

This patch fixes all issues related to IPv6 on NetApp ONTAP drivers.

Closes-bug: 1788419
Closes-bug: 1788460
Change-Id: I6eeca47997c7134d6604874bea48eab7cab6c1a2
(cherry picked from commit 925376527e356ed14320716d0f72b48b13b8aecb)

commit_message:
Move bionic jobs to voting, add release note.

Bionic check jobs are now passing so move these to voting and
add gate/periodic jobs for bionic.

Introduce a release note detailing the major changes and indicating
a viable upgrade path from Xenial to Bionic.

Change-Id: I0897e4f22b3949ce07a2ea0f2ee9c4f45c344e04
(cherry picked from commit a9d422151a75f654370e1a06a0b8e232c3740bb6)

Naturally if CI does not pass, we should not try and merge this patch (Well, we wouldn't anyway)."}, {'account_id': 20414, 'date': '2018-01-17 00:22:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-01-17 14:35:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-01-17 17:35:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Nice!'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-01-18 11:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/pike as commit 9347e60f9bde5d7f6f1a781082a713f5882067df'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:51:50.000000000', 'content': 'Created a revert of this change as I03f53a50ada9aabe9e3fbb71106d5190ae110e01'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-16 21:28:16.000000000', 'message': 'Use dd conv=sparse when writing images to nodes

When using whole disk images, one generally wants the *virtual*
size of the image to be close to the size of the overcloud nodes'
physical disks (since no partition/logical volume/filesystem
expansion is done). As an example, one might end up with a 4GB
overcloud image (QCOW file) that has a virtual size of 100GB or
more.

Ironic uses qemu-img to convert this QCOW file to a "raw" image,
which is a *sparse* file. When the image is copied to an overcloud
node's disk (via iSCSI), we currently write all 100GB (mainly of
zeroes) across the network to the node's disk.

Adding conv=sparse to the dd command makes it skip the "holes" in
the image file; it will only the write the portions of the image
that actually contain data across the network.

Closes-Bug #1743651

Change-Id: Ief3688b210c3b19ce8be45c5f9571b7ba6e79127
'}, {'created': '2018-01-17 00:22:52.000000000', 'message': 'Use dd conv=sparse when writing images to nodes

When using whole disk images, one generally wants the *virtual*
size of the image to be close to the size of the overcloud nodes'
physical disks (since no partition/logical volume/filesystem
expansion is done). As an example, one might end up with a 4GB
overcloud image (QCOW file) that has a virtual size of 100GB or
more.

Ironic uses qemu-img to convert this QCOW file to a "raw" image,
which is a *sparse* file. When the image is copied to an overcloud
node's disk (via iSCSI), we currently write all 100GB (mainly of
zeroes) across the network to the node's disk.

Adding conv=sparse to the dd command makes it skip the "holes" in
the image file; it will only the write the portions of the image
that actually contain data across the network.

Closes-Bug #1743651

Change-Id: Ief3688b210c3b19ce8be45c5f9571b7ba6e79127
'}]
commit_message:
Use dd conv=sparse when writing images to nodes

When using whole disk images, one generally wants the *virtual*
size of the image to be close to the size of the overcloud nodes'
physical disks (since no partition/logical volume/filesystem
expansion is done). As an example, one might end up with a 4GB
overcloud image (QCOW file) that has a virtual size of 100GB or
more.

Ironic uses qemu-img to convert this QCOW file to a "raw" image,
which is a *sparse* file. When the image is copied to an overcloud
node's disk (via iSCSI), we currently write all 100GB (mainly of
zeroes) across the network to the node's disk.

Adding conv=sparse to the dd command makes it skip the "holes" in
the image file; it will only the write the portions of the image
that actually contain data across the network.

Closes-Bug #1743651

Change-Id: Ief3688b210c3b19ce8be45c5f9571b7ba6e79127

- gate-tempest-dsvm-patrole-member-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/94/498594/2/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-patrole-member-ubuntu-xenial/20909f2/ : FAILURE in 51m 37s

- gate-tempest-dsvm-patrole-multinode-member-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/94/498594/2/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-patrole-multinode-member-ubuntu-xenial-nv/4cc8f6f/ : FAILURE in 45m 07s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2017-08-31 16:54:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

Do have a few questions about this:

1) Do we have to implement a fallback_rule for all rules if they don't match the one from N-1 or N-2?

2) If not, is this going to be an optional kwarg for users using N-1, N-2? If so, is there an advantage using this new kwarg over changing "rule" kwarg for, say, Newton for all tests that need to be changed?

Only way I can see this being beneficial is if users decide to create a fork off master, add their fallback rules, then upgrade from N-2 to N-1, for example, then don't have to make many changes at all to their code base.'}, {'account_id': 25100, 'date': '2017-08-31 17:27:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Do have a few questions about this:
 > 
 > 1) Do we have to implement a fallback_rule for all rules if they
 > don't match the one from N-1 or N-2?
The thinking was at least on my end that I would add them as I hit them, and should the rules differ each release to instead implement them as a list and then iterate over them. 

 > 
 > 2) If not, is this going to be an optional kwarg for users using
 > N-1, N-2? If so, is there an advantage using this new kwarg over
 > changing "rule" kwarg for, say, Newton for all tests that need to
 > be changed?
 > 
 > Only way I can see this being beneficial is if users decide to
 > create a fork off master, add their fallback rules, then upgrade
 > from N-2 to N-1, for example, then don't have to make many changes
 > at all to their code base.

I like that logic change, that should make it better, the problem I ran into was how on earth to write a test to cover that. Got stuck there. I'm thinking of having _check_rule_is_authorized to be callable with a list of rules to check, and return a set of results. That would allow like in the future for a depends_on and soft_depends_on type thing to each test'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2017-08-31 19:17:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > (2 comments)
 > >
 > > Do have a few questions about this:
 > >
 > > 1) Do we have to implement a fallback_rule for all rules if they
 > > don't match the one from N-1 or N-2?
 > The thinking was at least on my end that I would add them as I hit
 > them, and should the rules differ each release to instead implement
 > them as a list and then iterate over them.
 > 
 > >
 > > 2) If not, is this going to be an optional kwarg for users using
 > > N-1, N-2? If so, is there an advantage using this new kwarg over
 > > changing "rule" kwarg for, say, Newton for all tests that need to
 > > be changed?
 > >
 > > Only way I can see this being beneficial is if users decide to
 > > create a fork off master, add their fallback rules, then upgrade
 > > from N-2 to N-1, for example, then don't have to make many
 > changes
 > > at all to their code base.
 > 
 > I like that logic change, that should make it better, the problem I
 > ran into was how on earth to write a test to cover that. Got stuck
 > there. I'm thinking of having _check_rule_is_authorized to be
 > callable with a list of rules to check, and return a set of
 > results. That would allow like in the future for a depends_on and
 > soft_depends_on type thing to each test

You'll want to exploit this trick:

with mock.patch.object(rbac_rule_validation, '_check_rule_is_authorized') as mock_is_authorized:
    mock_is_authorized.side_effect = [rbac_exceptions.RbacParsingException, None, None]
    # do the test here
    # will cause the default rule to fail
    # so then the next code block dealing with using the fallback_rule is executed'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 02:23:53.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 25100, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:31:10.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-08-28 20:46:14.000000000', 'message': "Adds the ability to use a version specifier for patrole tests

This allows a test to test against different policy rules based on the
version of OpenStack that it is testing against. This allows the current
version of patrole to test older versions of OpenStack.

This commit changes the rule parameter in rbac_rule_validation to a
dict, with the key 'default' being the default behavior on the current
version. However, since the rule enforcement changes from version to
version, it also allows the user to specify a config value
openstack_test_version which is a different key in the test rule dict.
This other key can contain the older policy rule that older versions of
OpenStack used to control a certain action.

Change-Id: I48fea3313f3c045545965a9f0b57874dd5ffcc2f
"}, {'created': '2017-08-29 21:06:37.000000000', 'message': '[DRAFT]: Add the ability to use a fallback rule for older versions

This commit adds a fallback_rules parameter, which can contain an
additional rule to test against for older versions of OpenStack that
may have less granular policy rules.

Change-Id: I48fea3313f3c045545965a9f0b57874dd5ffcc2f
'}]
commit_message:
[DRAFT]: Add the ability to use a fallback rule for older versions

This commit adds a fallback_rules parameter, which can contain an
additional rule to test against for older versions of OpenStack that
may have less granular policy rules.

Change-Id: I48fea3313f3c045545965a9f0b57874dd5ffcc2f

I think that more useful then simple UT could be some fulstack test which will do something like:
1. Spawn VM (port)
2. Check if port is ACTIVE and admin port state is UP
3. Make admin port state to DOWN
4. Check if port status is DOWN as should be expected

If You don't know what are fullstack tests, You can check them in https://github.com/openstack/neutron/tree/master/neutron/tests/fullstack (You can check e.g. test_connectivity for an example).
If You need any help on such tests, please ping me - I will try to help as much as I will can."}, {'account_id': 27274, 'date': '2017-12-12 21:33:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27274, 'date': '2017-12-12 21:40:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 27274, 'date': '2017-12-12 21:42:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
[OVS] Shut down the port on changing the admin-state to false

On changing the port-admin-state to false, the port goes down.

Change-Id: Ica46e39d8858f4235a8a1b9caeb696346a86f38b
Closes-bug: #1672629

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: If94bb46e1993af57cc75804b8dc7a610dd949c24
Story: #2002586
Task: #24310

'}, {'created': '2018-08-11 02:02:32.000000000', 'message': "Convert OS-FEDERATION to flask native dispatching

Convert OS-FEDERATION to flask native dispatching.

NOTE: Two changes occured that impact testing in this patch.
      * The JSON Home test now uses assertDictEquals to make it
        easier to debug json_home document errors

      * It was by general good luck that the overloaded relation
        'identity_providers' worked as expected. The relation was
        used for both '/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers' and
        the Identity-Provider-Specific WebSSO path. The change
        to the JSON Home document and the tests make the
        Identity-Provider-Specific WebSSO path now a relation
        of 'identity_providers_websso' to more closely align
        with 'websso' relation for
        '/auth/OS-FEDERATION/websso/{protocol_id}'. While
        this constitutes a minor break in our contract (the
        output of the json home document) it was required to
        ensure consistency and functionality. The alternative
        is to not represent '/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers'
        (list endpoint) in the JSON Home document at all, instead
        represent only the WebSSO endpoint.

Change-Id: If746c14491322d4a5f88fa0cbb31105f6d38c240
Partial-Bug: #1776504
"}, {'created': '2018-08-11 23:11:03.000000000', 'message': "Convert OS-FEDERATION to flask native dispatching

        of 'identity_providers_websso' to more closely align
        with 'websso' relation for
        '/auth/OS-FEDERATION/websso/{protocol_id}'. While
        this constitutes a minor break in our contract (the
        output of the json home document) it was required to
        ensure consistency and functionality. The alternative
        is to not represent '/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers'
        (list endpoint) in the JSON Home document at all, instead
        represent only the WebSSO endpoint.

commit_message:
Convert OS-FEDERATION to flask native dispatching

Convert OS-FEDERATION to flask native dispatching.

NOTE: Two changes occured that impact testing in this patch.
      * The JSON Home test now uses assertDictEquals to make it
        easier to debug json_home document errors

      * It was by general good luck that the overloaded relation
        'identity_providers' worked as expected. The relation was
        used for both '/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers' and
        the Identity-Provider-Specific WebSSO path. The change
        to the JSON Home document and the tests make the
        Identity-Provider-Specific WebSSO path now a relation
        of 'identity_providers_websso' to more closely align
        with 'websso' relation for
        '/auth/OS-FEDERATION/websso/{protocol_id}'. While
        this constitutes a minor break in our contract (the
        output of the json home document) it was required to
        ensure consistency and functionality. The alternative
        is to not represent '/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers'
        (list endpoint) in the JSON Home document at all, instead
        represent only the WebSSO endpoint.

Change-Id: If746c14491322d4a5f88fa0cbb31105f6d38c240
Partial-Bug: #1776504

commit_message:
Set OVS local ip through OVS ODL class

OVS local IP is currently set through
puppet-tripleo's neutron ovs agent class.
Instead set it through ovs odl class.

Change-Id: I5f6e8b76eeac75298f11d69441b9ad08a5c51005
Partial-Bug: #1789371

subject: Fix how Mistral calculates workflow output
messages: [{'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-09-13 10:22:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 27008, 'date': '2018-09-13 10:29:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-09-13 12:28:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2018-09-13 13:11:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-13 10:22:35.000000000', 'message': 'Fix how Mistral calculates workflow output

* Workflow output sometimes is not calculated correctly due to
  the race condition between different transactions: the one that
  checks workflow completion (i.e. calls "check_and_complete") and
  the one that processes action execution completion (i.e. calls
  "on_action_complete"). Calculating output sometimes was based on
  stale data cached by the SQLAlchemy session. To fix this, we just
  need to expire all objects in the session so that they are
  refreshed automatically if we read their state in order to make
  required calculations. See the bug description for more details
  on how the problem was observed.
* Added another test for direct workflow that formally checks
  calculation of workflow output. It doesn't pretend to test the
  aforementioned issue (it can be reproduced only with a big number
  of attempts, and/or under load). It's for the sake of the test
  module completeness.

Change-Id: I4a7e7fd9a4bbb6e93df169b4b40bc2d83ccfce89
Closes-Bug: #1792090
(cherry picked from commit dfdff78315f72999dbd269e5fc4c4065a1b13013)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix how Mistral calculates workflow output

* Workflow output sometimes is not calculated correctly due to
  the race condition between different transactions: the one that
  checks workflow completion (i.e. calls "check_and_complete") and
  the one that processes action execution completion (i.e. calls
  "on_action_complete"). Calculating output sometimes was based on
  stale data cached by the SQLAlchemy session. To fix this, we just
  need to expire all objects in the session so that they are
  refreshed automatically if we read their state in order to make
  required calculations. See the bug description for more details
  on how the problem was observed.
* Added another test for direct workflow that formally checks
  calculation of workflow output. It doesn't pretend to test the
  aforementioned issue (it can be reproduced only with a big number
  of attempts, and/or under load). It's for the sake of the test
  module completeness.

Change-Id: I4a7e7fd9a4bbb6e93df169b4b40bc2d83ccfce89
Closes-Bug: #1792090
(cherry picked from commit dfdff78315f72999dbd269e5fc4c4065a1b13013)

commit_message:
Fix available roles listing

This change updates the expression which filters roles by role_tags.
In case when there are no role_tags defined in plan-environment.ymal
The expression should return all available roles

Closes-Bug: 1784605
Change-Id: I81051b0321c42c1b02974c5de310de88fb1a9d8b

commit_message:
Set the address of the IPv6 router port in logical switch back to 'router'

The commit [1] changed the address of the router port in lsp to the
port's mac address to fix the IPv6 Neigh Adv issue. The issue is
now fixed in core OVN [2]. So this patch sets back the address to
'router'.

[1] - I815ce0996f66f6b101c2151a8389a8b3fbe026f6
[2] - https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/commit/bec7c6415d1d770c90ff32e3626c0f63d55763af

Change-Id: Id95481d51360b73722aaed9b7c9b4ab437b1eb10
Closes-bug: #1788684
